title: SB 1.18.29-30 | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 18-04-2023 | Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya Narayanam Namaskritya Naramchaiva Narottamam Deveem Saraswateem Vyasam Tato Jayam Udi Rayet
segments.summary: The session begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras, setting the spiritual tone for the discourse.

segments.key_quote: In this session we will be discussing from two verses, the 29th and the 30th verses of the 18th chapter of the first canto of Shri Madbhagavatam.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the verses to be discussed, focusing on the unprecedented anger and envy of King Parikshit towards a Brahmana sage.

segments.key_quote: The king's anger and envy directed toward the Brahmana sage were unprecedented being that circumstances had made him hungry and thirsty.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the unprecedented nature of a devotee king like Parikshit becoming angry and envious towards a sage, highlighting the rarity of such an event.

segments.key_quote: The king knew well that Brahmanas, sages, children, women and old men are always beyond the jurisdiction of punishment.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the Vedic cultural context where the king protects citizens, especially Brahmanas, sages, children, women, and old men, who are given special care and are generally exempt from punishment.

segments.key_quote: The third category of protection special protection for citizens is the children.
segments.summary: The speaker continues to elaborate on the king's responsibility to protect vulnerable groups like children, women (especially widows and orphans), and the elderly, even overlooking minor mistakes they might make.

segments.key_quote: The king even though he commits a great mistake is never to be considered a wrong doer.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the concept that a king is generally not considered a wrongdoer, even if he makes mistakes, and emphasizes that the situation with Parikshit Maharaj was orchestrated by the Lord.

segments.key_quote: The only justification for Maharaj Pariksit's behaviour is that he was it was ordained by the lord.
segments.summary: The speaker reiterates that Parikshit's unusual behavior was arranged by the Lord, and that the king's actions, though seemingly wrong, were part of a divine plan.

segments.key_quote: Satu Brahma Risher Amse Gatasum Uragam Rusha Minir Dacchan Dhanush Kotya Nidhaya Puram Agatah
segments.summary: The speaker introduces and translates the 30th verse, describing how King Parikshit, feeling insulted, placed a dead snake on the shoulder of the meditating sage.

segments.key_quote: Although the king was never accustomed to such silly actions, why should he take so seriously the sage not receiving him under the circumstances?
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Parikshit's action of placing the dead snake was a 'tit for tat' response to feeling insulted, but emphasizes that this behavior was unprecedented for a devotee king dealing with a sage and was ultimately orchestrated by the Lord.

segments.key_quote: It is something that Krishna has arranged with a higher plan so that we have to always understand by the descriptions being given here by Suta Goswami.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by stressing that the events are part of Krishna's divine plan and encourages listeners to understand the deeper meaning, promising further details in the next video.
